title: Is an FDCPA lawsuit really worth the trouble?
question: I had a recent problem with a debt collector, and they ended up violating my state and federal debtor's rights, of which I have sold proof. When I called them on it in writing, and mentioned I reserved my right to sue, they sold or transferred the account to another collection agency. Now I'm working things out with Agency B, which seems to be more professional.
answers:
Always worth it. Costs you nothing and could get you the $1,000.00 statutory damages and wipe out the debt in dispute.

ABSOLUTELY it is "worth it!" Hire a consumer protection attorney in your area, he or she will do most of the work for you and simply send you a check when the case is settled. At some point, if the case does not settle, your attorney will be able to counsel you on whether going to trial will be "worth it."

Your State law violations could also significantly boost your statutory recovery. In NH, under RSA 358-C, you would be entitled to $200 PER VIOLATION.

Other benefits include holding the offending parties accountable and supporting your local consumer protection attorney. These consumer claims are very low value and fighting big business is expensive. It is important to make sure that you have an attorney in your community who can fight for the rights of consumers and still make a living. On the flip side, debt collection is a VERY lucrative business and if we don't hold the unscrupulous violators accountable, they will only proliferate. Essentially, it is your civic duty to sue a debt collector who brazenly violates the law in order to protect others who may not be as well educated as you about their rights.

Good Luck!
Atty. Jake Skinner

$1,000 statutory damages, your attorney's fees paid and no debt .. that is worth it to me. If there are actual damages, you can add that too. Be careful though because you have one year from the alleged violation to sue.

I agree with the second attorney. It is often worth it. You should consult with a consumer rights attorney in your area, as if he/she thinks the case is worthy they will most likely take on a contingency basis and seek their attorneys fees from the debt collector. A good source to find such an attorney is at As you do not mention what rights have been violated, this may be an actual damages case in addition to the potential $1,000 in statutory damages available under the FDCPA. Also, although I do not practice in CA, your state has a pretty strong unlawful debt collection practices statute of its own which may significantly add to the relief. Even if the case is just a "statutory damages" case, there more reasons than a significant money award to make it "worth it". Having your rights vindicated is relief in itself, and consumers who act to protect their rights send a strong message to these violators that their unlawful tactics are not good business. Feel free to visit my website here for more general info about unlawful debt collection.

In order for the suit to be worthwhile, the person would have to have sustained other damages from the collector, or there have to be multiple counts of violations. I feel it is much better to go to law enforcement, such as the agencies regulating the collection industry, for action rather than civil court.

Hope this perspective helps!
